stealing, on the 2nd of February , 2 shifts, value 2s.; 2 petticoats, value 3s.; 1 gown, value 4s., and 1 apron, value 8d. , the goods of
Catherine Whitaker
.

THOMAS BRETT
(Police-constable N 139). I was in the Green-lanes on the 2nd of February; I stopped the prisoner with a bundle, and asked him what he had got - he said he did not know; I asked where he was going to take it - he said to Mr. Clifton, salesman, Newgate-market, and he had brought it from Mr. Mattherson's, at Enfield, where he said he was ostler, and had been so four months; I took him - in going to the station he jumped away; I jumped after him - I fell down, and lost him; he was taken on Wednesday evening.
CATHERINE WHITAKER. These are my things; I lived at Mr. Mattherson's - the prisoner did not live there, but was-post boy at Mr. Ryder's, and used to come there every night, and go back every morning.

Prisoner's Defence. A young man overtook me with this bundle, and asked if I was going to London; I said I was - he asked me to take this to the Peacock, at Islington for him; he said, "I live at the George Inn, Enfield"- I said, "I do not think you do; I was there five or six months ago, and you did not live there then" - he said that person was gone away, and he said, "If you will take it, I will give you sixpence;" I said I should be stopped, and so I was.

THOMAS BRETT
. The parcel was directed.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

659.
REBECCA FISHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 23 yards of lace, value 12s., and eight handkerchiefs, value 6s. , the goods of
Daniel Stubbs
.

JAMES CROSBY
. I am shopman to Mr. Daniel Stubbs, haberdasher , Church-street, Hackney
. On the 14th of February the prisoner came and asked for some pillow-lace, for children's caps: she looked at that, and then asked for some handkerchiefs - I watched her, and told her I had suspicion of her; I opened her cloak, and found eight handkerchiefs under her arm - this piece of lace dropped from her lap; she said she had nothing.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was she not sitting down? A. Yes; she might have gone away - I was serving a customer; the prisoner was sitting on the lefthand side of the shop, and I was serving on the right, my face was towards her - she had asked Mrs. Stubbs for the lace, and then for the handkerchiefs, but Mrs. Stubbs had just then asked some ladies to take a seat; she was about half a yard from the door.

JANE MATTHEWS
. I am the wife of
David Matthews
. On the afternoon of the 14th of February, I went to the shop - the prisoner came after I was there; Mrs. Stubbs said she would serve her directly - she asked for somelace; there was none to suit her - she then asked for some handkerchiefs; she showed her some cotton ones - she said No, she wanted silk; some ladies came in - Mrs. Stubbs asked them to sit down, and the prisoner took a seat; I saw her draw something into the arm-hole of her cloak, but I could not see what it was - before I had an opportunity of telling the shopman, he went and took the handkerchiefs from under her arm, and the lace dropped down.
Cross-examined. Q. Did this child make the least attempt to go away? A. No, she was waiting to look at some silk shawls.

CHARLES DEWING TYLER
(Police-serjeant N 10). I was on duty at the watch-house, and the prisoner was given into my custody - I produce the articles.
Cross-examined. Q. There is no great bulk in them? A. No, she might have escaped with them.

JAMES CROSBY
. These are my master's handkerchiefs and lace.
Cross-examined. Q. She was searched in the parlour? A. Yes, Sir; I was not present - I heard that half a crown was found on her.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not intend to take them - I was standing or leaning on them, and I did not know it.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

661.
JAMES EAST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February . 1 half-crown, and 15 shillings, the monies of
Robert Keith
, from his person .

ROBERT KEITH
. I was originally a Custom-house officer - I live in Brewer-street, Golden-square
. On the 14th of February I was carrying a loaf home - when I got to my own door I put down my umbrella to apply my key to the door - the umbrella opened again, and while I was attending to that, and trying to open the door, the prisoner came and offered to turn the key of the door for me - I let go my hand that he might turn it, as I knew him; he then put his hand into my pocket, and took out a little bag, with fifteen shillings and one half-crown in it; I did not speak to him, I only said, "Halloo, you scoundrel;" nor did he speak to me - I had the money safe just before.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. How long have you known him? A. Since the 29th of June; there was no person near us - it was about half-past eight o'clock in the evening; I did not raise an alarm - he pulled out the purse, and 4s. 6d. in sixpences flew out of it, into the passage - I picked them up: I had been at the Court of Requests the day before, and the prisoner spoke to me then; my son had a claim on him for 17s. rent - I was to call on him that day fortnight, and he said he would pay me, but I had no quarrel with him - I conceived he was a poor man, and not able to pay.

CHARLES DEWING
(Police-constable C 1.) I apprehended the prisoner at a public-house in Macclesfield-street, Soho - I had received information a little before ten o'clock, and left word for him to come; I found on him 7l. 5s. 5 1/2d.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe he is a butcher? A. Yes; I have known him some months - he has a shop at the corner of Newport-market; I had seen him about ten o'clock on the night of the robbery, but I did not take him, as I did not know of whom the complaint was made.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in my own shop at the time he says he was robbed.

HENRY WOODS
. I am a journey man butcher. The prisoner is a master butcher, and cuts meat in the front of a shop at the corner of Newport-market - on the 14th of February I saw him in his shop from between seven and eight o'clock till between eight and nine: I saw him for three-quarters of an hour, till very near half-past eight - he then left with his brother.
COURT. Q. How far is Brewer-street from there? A. About a quarter of a mile; I work in the same shop as the prisoner; Mr. Warren, my master, cuts at one front, and the prisoner at the other.

WILLIAM EAST
. I am the prisoner's brother. I was at his shop that evening; he shut up and left his shop with me a little before nine o'clock - I had been there all the afternoon; he came between seven and eight - we left a little before nine o'clock, and went to Mr. Green's, a butcher, in Crown-court, about five minutes' walk from Newport-market; we did not go into Mr. Green's shop, but stood at the door - I have a brother named Alfred who lives there, and we went to tell him of the death of my brother Frederick; we stood at the door a few minutes.

COURT. Q. How far is that from Brewer-street? A. I do not know Brewer-street, nor the prosecutor's; my brother died the same afternoon, about three o'clock - he was buried on Sunday, at St. Pancras church.

JOSEPH KIRBY
. I am landlord of the house the prisoner was taken from - I have known him near twelve months - he has had a very good character.

COURT. Q. Where did he lodge? A. I do not know, but on the afternoon of the 14th of February he came to my house, between four and five o'clock; he said he had lost a brother; he remained there till about half-past seven o'clock, and then went away - my house is about a hundred and fifty yards from his shop; he appeared to be distressed - I saw him again about ten o'clock that evening; I was not aware he was in the house then till the officer came - I then went up, and told the prisoner the officer wanted him; he came down, and went alone to the station-house; he came back, and was taken about half-past twelve o'clock - his shop is about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's.

ROBERT KEITH
. There was a very good light opposite my door, and I had a light in my passage; when he stooped down his face was close to me - I cannot be mistaken in him.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Six Months .

662.
WILLIAM PUMMELL
and
RICHARD NEWMAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

THOMAS TOOL
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Whitecross-place. On Thursday night, the 31st of January, I was in Church-street, about six o'clock; I saw the prisoners following two gentlemen - I watched them, and when they got to Hackney-road
I saw Pummell take a handkerchief out of one of the gentlemen's pockets, and give it to Newman; I told the gentleman, and said, "Thatis the person, lay hold of him;" Newman ran down a street or two, and I pursued him till he got to a street which is not a thoroughfare, and there I took him with the handkerchief in his hand; he begged hard of me to let him go, said he would give me 2s., and asked me to have something to drink - after some time I got him near the corner where the handkerchief had been stolen; I there met an officer, and gave him to him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you recollect what my Lord my said to you in last February Session? A. No, I do not recollect being here, but I might have been; I have been here several times - I do not know whether I have been here twenty times; I do not recollect prosecuting two men for stealing a handkerchief of
John Keats
' last February Session, but it might be so.

Q. Upon your solemn oath, did you not swear you saw one Johnson take the handkerchief from Mr. Keat's pocket and put it into his breeches; and after thus swearing, did not the Jury acquit the prisoners, and my Lord tell you never to show your face here again? A. I do not recollect it; I remember the name of Henry Johnson and
David Wells
- I recollect swearing that I saw Johnson put his hand into Mr. Keat's pocket and take out his handkerchief, and put it into his breeches; but the Jury acquitted the prisoner, because you stifled the case; I began to be a witness seven or eight years ago, in consequence of my father losing some shoes - I have prosecuted persons once or twice for taking handkerchiefs from persons unknown - I will swear it is not five times; I did not get my expences last time - I did not apply for them; I have always been praised by Judges and Magistrates - I did not get my expences, because you stifled the case altogether: I never think about expences - I suppose in the last twelve months I have got 10s. or 12s. - I may have got 2l. in twelve months.

JAMES THOMPSON
(Police-constable H 78).) I received Newman from Tool, and he pointed out Pummell to me, as I returned from Worship-street.
Newman's Defence. Two boys dropped the handkerchief; I took it up and ran across the road, and Tool took me.
NOT GUILTY .

663.
JANE CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of January , 1 jacket, value 3s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Sharp
.

HENRY LEE
(Police-constable K 262.) On the night of the 28th of January, I went to No. 5, Sun-court; I found the prisoner there - I asked her what she had done with the jacket, trousers, and waistcoat: she said she had given them to a man to sell, and she did not know where they were sold - I went with her to Hyam's, who said he had bought these clothes; Shelly was sent for, and he stated that the prisoner gave him the clothes to sell - he has been sent on board a shop, he was a deserter; the prosecutor gave his name as
John Sharp
before the Magistrate, but he is now gone to sea.

MARY ANN HOWARD
. I keep a house No. 2, Union-street
. The prisoner came there with a man on the 28th of January; I was called up into the room between nine and ten o'clock - the prisoner was gone; I found the man without his clothes, he had no clothes to put on, and I lent him my husbands; he stated before the Magistrate that his name was John Sharp.

HENRY HYAM
. I am a slop-seller, and live at No. 137, High-street, Shadwell. I know a man who went by the name of Shelly, he brought me these clothes, and I bought them for 2s.; the prisoner came in about a quarter of an hour afterwards, and asked if a man had sold some clothes there - I said Yes, for 2s.; she said, I want them back, "and she threw down 2s.;" but I would not let her have them, as I thought the man had sold them to pay her the money.

GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

664.
ROBERT COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 8 bottles, value 2s.; 1 1/2 pint of rum, value 3s., and 4 quarts of whiskey, value 1l., the goods of
Sophia Lash Tarbutt
and others .

SOPHIA LASH TARBUTT
. I am in partnership with my four sisters - we keep the Royal Hotel, in Leicester-square
- the prisoner was our porter for about five weeks In consequence of information I went into the kitchen, on the 12th of February; I saw a box belonging to him in a closet, I found in it seven bottles of whiskey, and one of rum; I have reason to believe it was ours, as we had a hogshead of whiskey in the cellar - there are lahels on two of the bottles, which I know; the officer asked the prisoner why he took it, and he said to distribute amongst his friends; he did not say where from.

Cross-examined. Q. What name is over the door? A.
Elizabeth Harris
; our license is in that name - my sisters and I divide the profits between us; the box was not locked.

CHARLES YOUNG
(Police-constable C 140). I was sent for, and went into the kitchen; I saw this liquor found in the box - the prisoner came in; I asked him how he came possessed of so much liquor; he said he drew it from a cask in the cellar that he was sorry he had done it, and he intended to distribute it among his friends.

SOPHIA LASH TARBUTT
. These are our bottles; the cellar is kept locked, and the key is in the bar - one of my sisters draws the liquor; the prisoner has nothing to do with the cellar, we suppose he must have taken the key in the night.
GUILTY. Aged 23.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

665.
ELIZABETH BAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 1 tea-caddy, value 3s. , the goods of
Charles Danieli
.

CHARLES PIERCE
. On the 14th of February I was in Oxford-street
, and saw the prisoner take a teacaddy from a board fixed outside a shop, and walk away; I told the prosecutor - his shopman followed her, and took her.

WILLIAM VAN
(Police-constable D 94). The prisoner was given to me; I found no money on her, but two breasts of mutton, five duplicates, a book, and two pairs of ladies shoes, quite new, with the ticket on them,"3s. 6d. a pair."

JAMES DALY
. I am shopman to Mr.
Charles Danieli
, a jeweller - he sells caddies; this is his caddy - the witness gave me information; I took the prisoner thirty yards off, with this caddy under her shawl, secreted.
Prisoner's. Defence. I was in great distress, and in an ill state of health

GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

666.
SOPHIA BIRCH
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 13th of February , 90 pieces of timber, value 10l.; 30 slates, value 2s.; 20 lbs. weight of lead, value 3s., and 1000 bricks, value 30s., the goods of
Charles Thorogood
, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MESSRS. CLARKSON and ROWE conducted the prosecution.

CHARLES THOROGOOD
. I have been a builder . I have some carcases of houses in the neighbourhood of the Alpha-cottages, Regent's-park
; I never gave the prisoner permission to take any thing from them - I do not know her.

EDWARD THOMAS
. I am a carpenter. I live in Earl-street, Lisson-grove, near the Alpha-cottages; I went to work close by the prisoner's - I know the carcases of houses which are close by the prosecutor's garden-wall, within fourteen or fifteen yards; I saw the prisoner's son in the yard of those carcases, and a great many more boys on the tops of the houses, tearing down the pots from the chimneys, then the bricks, and throwing them over the wall into the yard of the prisoner's cottage - the prisoner's son was throwing the bricks from the yard of these carcases into the prisoner's garden.

ANDREW DELLANEY
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Bridport-street, opposite the prisoner. I know these five carcases in front of her house - I have seen boys pulling down the bricks: the greatest depredation was in January; but recently I have seen timber carried by the back entrance into her cottage-garden, by lads - the pieces seemed exactly the same as these which are here.

ROBERT HARRISON
. I am a bricklayer, and live in Dorchester-place, very near the Alpha-cottages, and near the prisoner's house. I have seen boys on the carcases of the houses in question, pulling down the bricks, and other boys were throwing them towards the prisoner's garden, where I saw a bricklayer at work, building a wall.
COURT. Q. You have seen two or three boys who have gone out of Court? A. Yes, and one of them I can swear to as one of the boys; he is the tallest of them - I do not know his name.

CHRISTOPHER BUNKELL
. I am a builder - I live in Dorchester-place, and am agent to the ground landlord of these carcases. I went over these five carcases one day last week - I suppose they have sustained damage to the amount of 200l. and upwards; joists, bricks, and slates, have been taken away, the chimney-pots destroyed, and the carcases greatly demolished - I know where the prisoner lives; there is a door from her garden to the back part of these carcases - I went to her house with two boys last Wednesday; I saw the prisoner there, and said, "I understood you are encouraging these boys to destroy these houses, and loosen the timbers - I am credibly informed there is a quantity of the materials in your cottage;" she said there was no property in her house belonging to any one but herself - I told her I was confident there was, and I was going to get an officer with a search-warrant, unless the property was delivered up; I left a man to watch the premises - I went away, and returned the same day with the officer; I then told her, I should, as a friend, wish her to give up the timber belonging to these houses - she said, "Come in, Sir;" I walked in with the officer as far as the parlour-door; I then said, "Mrs. Birch, you have got a good deal of the property belonging to these houses, and I am authorised by the proprietor to require you to give it up;" she said, "O deary me, we have nothing belonging to these houses" - I turned and looked into the other parlour on the left hand, and saw, I suppose, fifty or sixty pieces of timber piled up - or probably more; I said, "This is the timber we are looking for" - she said "O no, I gave either 2l. 3s. or 3l. 3s. for them, and a load of bricks;" I said, "Who did you buy it of? you must have had a great burgain" - she said, "I bought it of Mr. Morand;" I said, "What, the broker" - she said,"Yes, he is a broker;" I suppose the value of a load of bricks and the timber I saw would be 10l. or 12l. - the bricklayer came in at the time, and she said, "Here is a man who can prove I had them of Mr. Morand; and I had some words about paying the balance of the money, and he saw it come;" she said to him, "Did not you, Mr. Milwood; did not you see it come" - he said, "I saw a load of bricks and a piece or two of timber;" I said, "Did you see all this?" - he said, No; I asked the prisoner if she had any receipt, and she said it should be given at a proper time; I said we should persevere, and she said we might do as we pleased - I begged of her repeatedly to give it up, but she refused; I said there would certainly be a prosecution follow, as the property belonged to these premises - she said it did not; I then went to my employer, and then went to the prisoner's premises with the officer, and found a large quantity of wood, I believe ninety-four pieces in the whole, also a small piece of lead worth about 2s., and some slates - I compared the timber found at the prisoner's with the remainder of the joists left on the buildings; it matched in length and size, and its being faulty at one end - it tallied in every respect, and I have no doubt whatever that it came from there - here are two pieces I can speak to more particularly; I have matched one piece to the place it came from in the carcases, and it matched to the greatest nicety - the ends of these pieces have been cut off and rubbed with dirt; I have seen boys on the carcases from time to time, (and among the rest, Barnes,) throwing bricks into the prisoner's garden.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How many times did you go to the prisoner's cottage? A. Three times, and the first time I told her the charge, and wished her to give it up, which she refused to do; I first went on the Wednesday, and then again on the Thursday - I am aware that at auctions property is bought for much less than at shops.
MR. ROWE. Q. Did the prisoner ever state that she purchased these goods at an auction? A. No, she did not.

FRANCIS KEYS. I am an officer of Marylebone. I went with this witness, on Friday morning last, to search the prisoner's house; I read my warrant to her, and told her she was in custody, and I was going to take her and the whole of the timber away - I had seen the timber there the day before, when I went to apprehend one of the persons who is to give evidence, and she then said she did not know any such person; I found more than ninety pieces of timber in her house, there was a whole van load - I examined it, and found about half of the ends had been sawed off in a roughish manner; it had been newly done, but some dirt had been rubbed over it to make it appear old;. I said to a person who was with me, that I supposed there was not much pigeon left on the tops of the houses, and the prisoner said, "Oh, deary me, I have got a piece of lead; I heard a great noise between four and five o'clock one morning; I got up, went to one of the houses, and found a piece of lead, which I have in the house" - I recollected that I had seen a piece of lead on a range, but it was then missing - I found it stuffed behind a grate; I found is a cupboard, a number of bits of wood split up - I said, "Mrs. Birch, what is this?" she said, "Only a little fire-wood, and the back of an old cupboard;" I said, "I shall take it away;" she put her hands on me, and said,"Oh, don't take my fire-wood away, it is only wood I have got to light my fire;" I said, "I shall take it, and keep your hands off, or it will be the worse for you;" this is it; when I went and said I came to take her and the timber, she said, "O Lord, what a piece of work there is about this timber - I bought it of a man of the name of Morand, and paid for it; I gave 3l. 3s. for it, and a quantity of bricks" - I said, "You had a very cheap bargain, have you any bill?" she pretended to look among some papers for it, but could not find it - she said she did not know where the man lived, but she afterwards told me where he had lived; I saw part of this timber fitted to the carcases - it matched according to my judgment.
Cross-examined. Q. She told you where Morand lived? A. Yes, but I went, and he had been dead nine weeks.

CHRISTOPHER BUNKELL
. I took the two boys on the Wednesday, but as I did not press any charge against them, they were discharged.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you happen to know that the prisoner is under a covenant to lay out money on her house? A. No.

WILLIAM BARNES
. I know the carcases at the back of the prisoner's house; I have been on them with the prisoner's son, carrying the wood out of these carcases into the prisoner's cottage - it was put into her kitchen; the prisoner was there, and I saw her daughter sawing off the ends of the wood we carried in - and the prisoner dirtied the ends with some dirt brought from the garden; I cannot tell how many times we took wood there, it was perhaps ten times.

WILLIAM BOWLER
. I was at the prisoner's on the Wednesday before she was taken - I was employed to hold the wood while they sawed it; the ends they sawed off were chopped up into small pieces like these.
Cross-examined. Q. Who chopped it? A. The other boy - Mrs. Birch employed him to do it.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought the wood of Morand for 3l. 3s., and 11s. for the bricks - I understood I was to have them free of cartage, but I had to pay for it; I was short of money, and did not pay him - he said he would bring a bill, and I was to pay him; I never employed either of the boys - they have had a bribe to appear against me; Thomas has been turned off our premises for committing nuisances, when the bricks and timber came to my house, I called Millwood, and asked him to come and unload, as I had no one to do it; he came and took the bricks, but he said he was using compo', and could not unload the timber - he said he did not think I had had a good bargain, for it was most of it decayed; we had had the sweeps on the Monday morning, and I suppose they put the lead down to keep the soot from the bricks - I have heard that the boys have thrown bricks over my premises, and I have had four sash squares broken; I have begged them to go away - the building next to us shakes with the wind, and the boys took the main rafter from them last week, and I begged them to go away; they brought some wood to my daughter - she would not buy it; they said they would make a good fire with it; I only employed the boy to cut up an old cupboard.

MR. CLARKSON to
WILLIAM BARNES
. Q. Did you receive money from the prisoner from time to time? A. Yes, for taking the wood into the house.

JAMES MILLWOOD
. I am a bricklayer, and have been occasionally employed by the prisoner - I remember a load of timber and bricks coming to her in November; I was at that time working for Mr. Griffiths - I ran over but as my labourer was mixing compo', I could not stop; I heard the prisoner arguing with the men at the gate, about 3s. they had overcharged for coming - on another occasion I saw a quantity of timber go in a cart; my brother was with me then measuring a foundation - I understand the prisoner has her cottage on a repairing lease.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you in the habit of frequenting that neighbourhood? A. I live within a short distance of it; I know there are some carcases - I do not know how many; I was the person who carried up the wall in her garden - the boys were not throwing bricks over into the garden while I was there; the wall I built was composed of old and new bricks - I should think four or five thousand new bricks was delivered from time to time; I do not know of any of the joints of the carcases being taken away - I have not received any money from the prisoner since she has been in custody; I did not notice whether the timber which came in the cart was such as these - I cannot tell whether the cart had one or two horses: I did not notice the same that was on it - I should not know the man who drove it; it was a fairish cart - it was bricks that came when there was the haggling about the money - I saw some old doors among the timber that came; there were some old doors - I cannot say whether there were any slates or not.

HENRY MILWOOD
. I am a bricklayer. I worked for the prisoner, in building a wall; I know the five carcases, they have been standing seven or eight years; I found the bricks on the premises, which I used in building the wall - a great many of them had been used before; I did not notice whether they were such as the carcases were built with - there are a great manyboys playing about there; but I know nothing about bricks being pulled down - I saw wood and bricks brought to the prisoner's house in a fairish sized cart, a rubbish cart; the person who brought it, does jobbing for bricklayers - I did not notice the colour of the horse, there were two at one time, and one the other - I do not know where the timbers were put in the prisoner's house - I was at my work in the back yard - the cart came by the street; I do not know any thing of the driver - I know there was a man making a dispute about some money; he was a tallish thin man - I did not notice his dress; it was some time in November - I never saw a single brick thrown from the houses while I was there.

MR. CLARKSON to
ROBERT HARRISON
. Q. Did you see this witness ? A. I did; he was building the wall while the boys were throwing the bricks over .

GUILTY. Aged 64.
Recommended to Mercy .
Confined Six Months , without Labour .

667.
MARIA BRYANT
was indicted for
stealing , on the 27th of January , 8s., the monies of
Francis William Herbrechter
, from his person .

FRANCIS WILLIAM HERBRECHTER
. I am a coachsmith . On the 27th of January I was in Boyd's-place , Shoreditch, at half-past two o'clock in the morning ; I had been spending the evening at a friend's at Hoxton, and as I was going by the end of Church-street, Shoreditch
, the prisoner accosted me; she told me a young man who was standing there was after no good - I proceeded on to the next turning, and then she came and wanted me to go home with her, which I refused; she then put her hand into my waistcoat pocket and took out my money - she went off; the officer was going by the top of the turning - he asked what I had lost; I told him, and he ran and took her with the money in her month .

WILLIAM HENRY CLARK
( Police-constable H 34). The prosecutor charged her with robbing him of 8s.; I took her and found she had something in her mouth, and I found it was this 8s .
Prisoner's Defence . I am innocent ; I did not mention any thing about any man .

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

668.
JAMES MAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of January , 1 book, value 10s. , the goods of
John Brooks
.

JOHN BRICKHILL
. I had information that a Bible had been stolen; on the 25th of January the prisoner came to our house, about twelve o'clock, and brought this Bible - I asked him his name, and where he lived; he said Evans , No. 11, Warner-street - I went there, but no such person lived there; he said he had had the book twenty years , and Brodie, of Spring-gardens, could answer that .

JOHN BROOKS
. I am a carpenter . This is my Bible ; I lost it from No. 9, Blandford-square
on the 23rd of January , from the front room; I do not know the prisoner .
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a young man whom he saw bring the Bible out of a shop, gave it to him to pledge .

WILLIAM EVANS
. I am the father of the prisoner. On the Wednesday when this book is represented to have been stolen, he was at home till eleven o'clock at night .
NOT GUILTY .

669.
JOHN JENKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of February , 4 lbs. of pork , value 2s. , the goods of
George Richardson
.

GEORGE RICHARDSON
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in High-street , Shadwell
. About ten o'clock on the evening of the 2nd of February, the officer brought the prisoner to my shop ; I missed a hand of pork - it was produced : I have not the least doubt it was mine .

ERASMUS CHARLTON
( Police-constable K 133). I saw the prisoner and another boy looking in at the prosecutor's window - the prisoner put his hand in, and took the hand of pork .

GUILTY Aged 14. -
Whipped and Discharged

670.
WILLIAM HENDON
was indicted for
stealing , on the 6th of February , 1 handkerchief , value 3s ., the goods of
Benjamin Dickison
, from his person .

BENJAMIN DICKISON
. I was in the New-road
on the 6th of February , between eleven and twelve o'clock in the day - I did not feel my handkerchief taken, but a man apprised me of it; I turned, and saw it in the middle of the road - the prisoner was pointed out to me , and I seized him.

JAMES PARTRIDGE
. I was going from Somer's-town , on the 6th of February , about twelve o'clock in the day ; I saw the prisoner and two others take hold of this gentleman's pocket; one of them took the handkerchief and gave it to the prisoner ; I seized him - he dropped it, and I took him to the office , he said he did not take it.

GUILTY . Aged 18 -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

671.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of February , 24 lbs. of beef , value 12s. , the goods of
Henry Howes
.

HENRY HORWOOD
. I am servant to Mr.
Henry Howes
; he is a butcher , and lives in Brook's-market
. On the 2nd of February I was at home , but did not see this meat taken ; I was told of it, and then missed some ribs of beef; I ran into Leather-lane, and saw the prisoner with it .

WILLIAM RAWLINSON
( Police-constable G 54). The prisoner was brought to the station - I asked if knew any thing about the meat ; he said he did not, but it was another boy he had formerly been with .

HENRY HALL
. I saw it in his possession - he threw it down ; I ran and took him - when I got back to our shop I found it there.
Prisoner. I saw a boy throw it down , and I took it up .

GUILTY . Aged 12. -
Transported for Seven Years .
